factoid: The countess replied "Yes".
The countess held out her hand to Prince Andrew.
The countess pressed her lips to Prince Andrew's forehead while he stooped to kiss her hand.
The countess wished to love Prince Andrew as a son.
The countess felt that Prince Andrew was a stranger to her.
The countess felt that Prince Andrew was a terrifying man.
The countess was sure her husband would consent to the marriage.
The countess said "but your father...".
Prince Andrew said that his father had made the wedding not to take place for a year.
Prince Andrew said that he wished to tell the countess about the condition.
Prince Andrew said "It is true that Natásha is still young, but—so long as that?...".
Prince Andrew said "It is unavoidable" with a sigh.
The countess said "I will send her to you".
The countess left the room.
The countess repeated "Lord have mercy upon us" while seeking her daughter.
Sónya said that Natásha was in her bedroom.
Natásha was sitting on the bed.
Natásha was pale.
Natásha was dry‑eyed.
Natásha was gazing at icons.
Natásha was whispering something.
Natásha was rapidly crossing herself.
Natásha jumped up and flew to her mother.
Sónya said "Go, go to him. He is asking for your hand".
Sónya said "Go… go" with a deep sigh.
Natásha never remembered how she entered the drawing room.
Natásha paused when she saw Prince Andrew.
Natásha asked herself "Is it possible that this stranger has now become everything to me?".
Natásha answered herself "Yes, everything! He alone is now dearer to me than everything in the world.".
Prince Andrew came up to Natásha with down‑cast eyes.
Prince Andrew said "I have loved you from the very first moment I saw you. May I hope?".
Prince Andrew looked at Natásha and was struck by the serious impassioned expression of her face.
Natásha's face said "Why ask? Why doubt what you cannot but know? Why speak, when words cannot express what one feels?".
Natásha drew near to Prince Andrew and stopped.
Prince Andrew took Natásha's hand and kissed it.
Prince Andrew asked Natásha "Do you love me?".
Natásha answered "Yes, yes!".
Natásha sighed loudly.
Natásha began to sob.
Natásha asked "What is it? What's the matter?".
Natásha replied "Oh, I am so happy!".
Natásha smiled through her tears.
Natásha bent over closer to Prince Andrew.
Natásha paused for an instant as if asking herself whether she might.
Natásha kissed Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew held Natásha's hands.
Prince Andrew looked into Natásha's eyes.
Prince Andrew did not find in his heart his former love for Natásha.
Prince Andrew felt pity for Natásha's feminine and childish weakness.
Prince Andrew felt fear at Natásha's devotion and trustfulness.
Prince Andrew felt an oppressive yet joyful sense of duty that bound him to Natásha forever.
Prince Andrew's present feeling was stronger and more serious than his former feeling.
Prince Andrew asked Natásha "Did your mother tell you that it cannot be for a year?".
Natásha thought "I—the 'chit of a girl', as everybody called me—".
Natásha thought "Is it possible that I am now to be the wife and the equal of this strange, dear, clever man whom even my father looks up to?".
Natásha thought "Can it be true? Can it be true that there can be no more playing with life, that now I am grown up, that on me now lies a responsibility for my every word and deed?".
Natásha thought "Yes, but what did he ask me?".
Natásha replied "No".
Prince Andrew said "Forgive me!".
Prince Andrew said "But you are so young, and I have already been through so much in life. I am afraid for you, you do not yet know yourself.".
Natásha listened with concentrated attention.
Natásha tried but failed to take in the meaning of Prince Andrew's words.

Prince Andrew said "Hard as this year which delays my happiness will be, it will give you time to be sure of yourself. I ask you to make me happy in a year, but you are free: our engagement shall remain a secret, and should you find that you do not love me, or should you come to love...".
Natásha interrupted Prince Andrew with "Why do you say that?".
Natásha said "You know that from the very day you first came to Otrádnoe I have loved you.".
